comments.commentBody: It is said that there is but a thin line between tragedy and comedy. And the first 100 days of the Trump administration is a perfect example of that saying. It is indeed very comical to see them bumbling around, huffing and puffing with great bravado. But it masks the tragic situation we are in - defunding of science, climate change, banging the drums of war, and causing unease throughout the world.

taxonomies.name: Today’s Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal (todays-energy-jobs-are-in-solar-not-coal)

newswire.title: Today’s Energy Jobs Are in Solar, Not Coal
newswire.abstract: Today’s energy jobs are in solar and, increasingly, wind power, rather than coal. But jobs are unevenly distributed across the country.

comments.commentBody:
Focusing on bringing back jobs in the coal mining industry is like trying to get us all to travel in a horse and buggy. I think even coal miners will resist that.
But, somehow, our liar-in-chief managed to convince enough folks that reviving jobs in coal mining is both useful and important. And here is the double whammy on those folks waiting to get back into the mines. Most of their jobs have been taken over by machines and for those that did actually mine, their healthcare is under attack.
So, not only are those coal mining jobs not coming back, but for those whose health was adversely afflicted in the coal mines, good luck getting proper healthcare.

asset.assetTitle: All I Know Is What I Read in the Fake News (25conversation)

taxonomies.name: All I Know Is What I Read in the Fake News (25conversation)

comments.commentBody:
Matt Labash is a lot more interesting than Arthur Brooks, although that was a low threshold to cross. As seems to be the case with many things including the POTUS these days. He does have a better sense of humor than his immediate predecessor although Gail Collins wins the gold!
Nonetheless I have a few points of disagreement with him. He accuses Team Blue (a nice term, thank you for introducing it to me) "of squirting down the working class’s leg while telling them that it’s raining" while conveniently forgetting it is technology that is killing more jobs than immigrants, legal or illegal.
He notes that he "distrust “my side” nearly as much as I distrust yours" meaning that he has no faith in Team Blue or Team Red. That is no argument because we need some form of governance structure. I suppose we could have more political parties with more color codes, but merely noting that neither side is "trustworthy" makes no sense. Part of the reason is the entrenched Congressmen/women who through legislative processes carve out districts that help them get reelected. Is Matt ready to call for an amendment that shifts redistricting to nonpartisan panels?

There is nothing inherently wrong in talking about or teaching western civilization as "an accumulation of great ideas and innovations, from the Egyptians, through Athens, Magna Carta, the Age of Faith, the Renaissance and the Declaration of the Rights of Man."
The problem is when one assumes that this is the ONLY narrative of human civilization and evolution as expressed by Congressman Stephen King who openly questioned if any "other categories of people" had made any contribution at all.
What we need is a broader understanding of human history and evolution that goes beyond western civilization.

comments.commentBody:
One of the many problems in international affairs is that there are various state actors with various interests in various configurations. Some dictators - e.g., Saudi Arabia - are friendly to America whereas others - e.g., North Korea - are not. And managing these relationships is a delicate business that requires more patience and less bluster.
And the one thing we know about Trump is that he is all bluster. But there is hope. North Korea and America share a similarity in their leaders. As Ms. Collins notes, both are "narcissistic to the point of psychosis, with a celebrity fixation and a very strange haircut." Maybe this will be helpful. And Dennis Rodman can be the go between!

comments.commentBody: According to candidate Trump, Obama was at fault for showing his hand to the enemy. He often would use that to ridicule and his simple-minded supporters fell for that hook line and sinker. But now President Trump (two words that should not go together, as Colbert often notes) tweets at an hourly rate telling the whole world about his latest peeve. Is he not showing his hand? I wonder. But his supporters are thrilled that America flexed her muscles, not bothering to worry about the downstream effects of such macho posturing. To Trump and his acolytes thumping on one's chest is what makes America Great Again.

comments.commentBody:
Noting the similarity with biological mutation, Joseph Schumpeter wrote about industrial mutation as a process "that incessantly revolutionizes the economic structure from within, incessantly destroying the old one, incessantly creating a new one." In other words in a thriving economy jobs are created even as old ones are destroyed.
But politicians, especially ones who are themselves ignorant often like to point and blame either liberals or foreigners as causes for job losses in order to garner political advantage. It is therefore easy to appeal to the coal mining and manufacturing sector employees by telling them that there is a well identified enemy that is causing their job loss. It is much harder when there is no specific target that can be easily identified.
The simple fact of the matter is that many manufacturing jobs have been automated and in a typical car manufacturing plant one robot replaces three workers. Is any politician going to identify robots as the cause of and therefore the enemy to be rooted out?
A smart and thoughtful politician will take the time to explain that job creation in new sectors with new technologies is the way to blunt these losses, not fight the target enemy to bring back those lost jobs. But then again that takes both smartness and honesty, two characteristics notably absent among our representatives. .

comments.commentBody:
Granted Governor Cuomo did not engage in public hearings or call for research by scholars before taking this leap. As a result it seems he was going for the headlines more than actually fixing a problem.
But, if we take him and his aides at their word, why not get started and then fine tune. As has often been noted in many other contexts, let us not make the perfect the enemy of the good.
Take Obamacare as an example. Even its supporters will agree it was not perfect. There were strong political reasons for its enactment. But, if our Congress was filled with folks interested in governing and not preening (an accusation that is being hurled at Cuomo on this very subject), they would look at how it is functioning and fine tune it.
So, bottom line, I'm prepared to wait and see how this policy works and then begin to modify it as its effects begin to manifest.

comments.commentBody:
India is an enigma. For anything anyone points to, someone else will point to the opposite. You'll see phenomenal expressions of secularism and tolerance on the same day you'll also see religious venom being spewed. The technological progress is evident in pockets even as you see some poor live without electricity or access to decent toilets. There's a man driving out of his house in a Mercedes Benz alongside a vendor pulling a handcart filled with vegetables for sale.
India simultaneously lives in the past and the future, in the nineteenth and twenty-second centuries. Truly, India is a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma.

comments.commentBody:
The fundamental point that effectiveness must trump purity is an important one to recognize. This is a good lesson for protesters to follow.
But what about the fawning media? They are perplexed in how to cover Trump. This is where they need to abandon their long-held belief in "balanced" coverage. When Trump says that the earth is flat, they should not be bringing in the one person who believes it and have him debate the issue with another person (who is one from a billion) giving the impression of "fairness." They need to call a spade a spade.
This is where satire and comedy comes into play. Our comedians are doing a much better job of covering Trump than the standard issue journalist. The one exception maybe Jake Tapper. For a full review check out the following link:

http://www.vox.com/2017/4/3/15163170/strikethrough-comedians-satire-trum...

taxonomies.name: Reaching Out to the Voters the Left Left Behind (13edsall)

comments.commentBody:
I have a quibble with the title of this column. It says that the Left left behind some Americans who then switched to vote for the other team. It makes for a cute use of the word "left" but is otherwise incorrect.
The jobs recover rate was slower in the nonmetropolitan areas; that much is a fact. But it is a giant leap from there to say that they were left behind. For one, there was a big public investment that helped some of the unemployed. It was not big enough because of the right. And then there was the healthcare access that must have helped offset some economic hardship and mental tension. Here too, it is worth noting that there was uniform opposition from the right. And then in 2015-16 the slow growth and recovery was pinned on the left by the right with Trump leading the charge. Somewhere in all of this was the trumped up toxic charge that Obama was a secret Kenyan Muslim.
And now reading the title of this column makes my head spin. We have truly entered a new world where up is down and left is right.
Yes, the left is right and the right is wrong!

comments.commentBody:
The comparison between the heat being felt by the Republican members now and the one inflicted by the Tea Party in 2010 is yet another false comparison. More than that it is odious.
Folks today are protesting the stripping away of health care, something that was made possible by the very man that the Tea party was protesting in 2010. Today they feel their support being yanked away by this feckless Congress led by the two-faced Ryan, whereas in 2010 they felt uncomfortable and threatened with the fact that an Africa-American rose to get the top job.
Brooks' comparison is worse, much worse, that Spicer's comparison of Assad and Hitler. How low can these comparisons go?

comments.commentBody: It is "virtual ISIS" that is a problem. Why? Because it is an idea, an idea that the Islamic world has been subjugated by the western, Christian, secular world. And ideas are powerful, very powerful. Once they catch on, they catch fire and spread. Need proof? Just think of America. Yes, America, the country we live in. There is a physical territory associated with it. But it is the idea of America and what it stands for that attracts people all over the world. It is "virtual America" that attracts people.

comments.commentBody:
This was a poor showing by any standards. First the forced removal, arguably legal and within UA's rights, of a seated passenger, only to be followed by an apology for an apology by the CEO. To say it was not a shining moment would be stating the obvious.

However, angry Americans, it seems, are also creative Americans. The internet went abuzz with creative mottos, such as:
We put hospital in hospitality.
We treat you like we treat your luggage.
We have first class, business class, and no class.
Our prices are unbeatable, but we can't say the same for our passengers.
Board as a doctor, leave as a patient.
If we can't beat our competitors, we can beat our customers.

Thank you sir, for standing for your rights even when being dragged.

newswire.abstract: The life of the mind, then and now.

comments.commentBody:
Brooks differentiates between intellectuals of the past with thought leaders of today.
The dictionary defines an intellectual as one possessing intellect, which is defines as "the faculty of reasoning and understanding objectively, especially with regard to abstract or academic matters." To the extent that "reasoning and understanding objectively" have taken a back seat to instant gratification and twitter-mania, I agree that there is less and less weight placed on intellectualism and intellectuals. This is not so much because intellectual have been wrong in the past - of course they have been - but because our attention span has been scaled down to 140 characters or less. For that matter, even TED talks that feature scholars is limited to 18 minutes.
Time impoverishment and attention deficit have forced intellectuals to now be pithy and evangelical. And that is why they have had to become "thought leaders" who champion "one big idea to improve the world."
The winds of change are upon us; the 20th century intellectual who embraced and advanced broad perspectives has been replaced by a 21st century thought-leader who proselytizes one idea at a time.

newswire.abstract: On Syria, we would all do well to temper the self-congratulatory war speeches and thrusting of pom-poms.

comments.commentBody:
This is Trump's "Wag the dog" moment. He saw an opportunity to unleash a few missiles and all of a sudden his approval rating kicks into high gear.
Syria, and for that matter, the entire Middle East is a mess ever since the colonial powers left the scene. America has inherited this region and has been trying to midwife, not once but many times, a peaceful set of state actors without much success.
The problems are deep and intractable and the solutions are few and hidden. Only a person with deep knowledge can even attempt to remedy this mess, and Trump does not seem to be that person. To him this is a show of power, an extension of the bully in personal matters now at the global level. He is least interested in resolution.

newswire.abstract: Hint: Winning news cycles is no substitute for the real thing.

comments.commentBody:
"One thing is certain: The media reaction to the Syria strike showed that many pundits and news organizations have learned nothing from past failures."
The real story is that the media is still being played like an accomplished concert violinist by Trump. Trump says he's save 1100 jobs in Indiana, and the media swoons even though that was factually incorrect and insignificant from a jobs policy perspective. Trump addresses Congress in complete sentences for almost one hour, and pundits anoint him as being presidential. And most recently, he authorized missile strikes in Syria and he is seen as being decisive.
I can understand his supporters feeling elated as these events unfolded. After all they are favorably disposed toward him and these actions seem impressive. But the pundits? The media? C'mon folks, you can do better than that.
Taxing Indiana citizens to save 700 jobs is not exactly a jobs creation program that can be sustained. Speaking at length somewhat coherently? Now that's what high school students are taught to do. And firing missiles does not signify the end of any conflict.
A magician who distracts his audience for producing an effect. The audience cheers, because they know they have been fooled. They are befuddled but they love it. Governance is serious business and no laughing matter. It is high time the media stopped cheering.

comments.commentBody: Trump's approval of Bill O'Reilly tells me about his own values. But, more importantly, it tells me about the values espoused by those who voted for him and the 35% that apparently continue to support him. Many pundits (most recently Kristof) have suggested that we should be understanding of those who voted for Trump. Does not his endorsement of O'Reilly give them any pause or regret? Apparently not. And, if so, why should we continue to assume that his supporters are not sexists, misogynists, or racists?

comments.commentBody:
David Brooks opines that we may not have "reached peak Trump." As he goes on to note that our incompetent "to recognize his own incompetence."

All of which reminds me of the famous Omar Khayyam quatrain:
He who knows not, and knows not that he knows not, is a fool. Shun him.
He who knows not, and knows that he knows not, is a child. Teach him.
He who knows, and knows not that he knows, is asleep. Wake him.
He who knows, and knows that he knows, is a leader. Follow him.

Our incompetent loudmouth-in-chief knows not, does not know he knows not, and is proud about being a know-nothing. The only thing more shocking that this is that nearly 35% support him!

newswire.abstract: Among the reader reactions: “I hate these people.”

comments.commentBody:
Comparing the homeless or the drug addict, for whom the liberals seem to have sympathy, to the Trump voter, for whom the liberals seem not to have sympathy, is superficial and does not do justice to the liberal. The superficial similarity is that both, the homeless or drug addict and the Trump voter, may have made bad choices and hence need our sympathy. But a second look informs us that the drug addicts choice does not potentially cause harm to society in the same manner that a bad choice for a President would. In case of the drug addict, the damages will be mostly to the person, his/her family & friends, and maybe the larger public will have to bear added costs to support treatment or rehabilitation. By electing Trump these voters have increased the chances of a catastrophe much larger than that. The potential for a war, even a nuclear war, with North Korea is growing stronger every day. Making such a comparison is facile but it is improper, but at least had a modicum of humanity.

By when you write that "Democrats didn’t do enough do address this suffering" (the Trump voter's suffering, that is) I lost you. I am sure you are more than aware that the red states have a net inflow of federal funds that are largely fed by the blue states. There is a redistribution going on and it is in favor of the Trump voter. And yet they believe in small government, one that promises healthcare for all and then cuts out 24 million Americans.

The two are not the same. Period.

Remember one of Trump's campaign promises that he knew the smartest people and would be the only one capable of hiring them. What he forgot to mention was that he knew one smart guy named Jared Kushner who he'd appoint to do all the presidential tasks.
As it turns out, JK isn't all that smart or competent. He was looking for White House staff (or help, as he might prefer to call them) but found that they depart when Obama departs. And now JK has to do it all by himself. But then again he's Superman!

newswire.abstract: Diversity’s threat to democracy, and the leadership we need.

comments.commentBody:
You hve posited two reasons why an authoritarian leader might exist. You offer Turkey's Erdogan as an example when "authoritarian rule evolves as a way for a majority or plurality group to hold power against the claims of diverse minorities, and to impose a kind of uniformity on weaker ethnic or religious groups." The second example you provide is that of Syria's Assad who "casts himself as a protector of diversity, promising to shield minorities who would be threatened should a majoritarian populism take power."

Let me suggest a third alternate that is best exemplified by our electing Trump recently. An under-educated, ill-informed, incurious segment that is easily taken in by the bombast of a rogue who promises them everything under the sun. It is the classic you can eat everything including the cake but still lose weight.

newswire.abstract: Why are big boasts turning into tiny policy tweaks?

comments.commentBody:
Besides the fact that this administration is filled with bombast, arrogance and incompetence, all of which have been demonstrated multiple times, the thing that stood out was the following:
"Mr. Trump then walked out of the room — without signing the orders. (Vice President Mike Pence gathered them up, and the White House claims that they were signed later.)"
This continues to show that Trump is driven by ego and self-interest and that everyone around him is an enabler. During the campaign it was Christie who was publicly shamed on numerous occasions. Now it is the Veep who picks up the unsigned executive orders and brings them along to his master's chambers for obtaining his signature.
How do these folks around him put up with this guy? Does not even one of them have the sense to call him on his outrageous and infantile behaviors? Are they so power hungry that they want to be seen near this man-child hoping that he'll drop them a bone from time to time?
That Trump is an empty vessel was, and continues to be, obvious. When will his sycophants tell him he's naked?

newswire.abstract: American life has secularized and grand political ideologies have fallen away, but moral conflict has only intensified.

comments.commentBody:
Brooks laments the current state of affairs in noting that "There is sin but no formula for redemption." He suggests that this state is caused by a decay that he blames equally on the left and right.
Blaming the left and the right was always a classic Brooks' approach, but after the 2016 election, it seemed that he was less inclined to use the "one-the-one-hand-but-on-the-other-hand" technique. He seems to have gone back to that in today's column.
There is no equivalence Mr. Brooks. It is high time a scholar like you said so.

newswire.abstract: Don’t overestimate Washington’s influence on energy markets, or underestimate the role of cities, states, businesses and consumers in cutting emissions.

comments.commentBody:
Bloomberg is right in so far that markets have been turning away from coal to cleaner sources. And, in that sense, Trump, or whoever sits atop Washington, is almost irrelevant. This is why Bloomberg writes, "There is virtually nothing the Trump administration can do to stop advanced technology and consumer preferences from driving down coal’s market share still further."
But, in the meantime, Trump can act and look like a fool. And I am perfectly fine with that except that he now represents me and other Americans. In the process, he threatens American leadership and influence around the world. And that is unacceptable.

comments.commentBody:
"A mind is a terrible thing to waste."
Who doesn't know or hasn't heard this tag line that has been in use by the United Negro College Fund since 1972.
But the GOP and Trump want people to be intellectually lazy, as they were in the 2016 election, for how else could one explain their rise to power. How else can we explain Trump's constant harangue of 'fake news?'
First they win by selling bogus ideas (building the wall), then they continue to starve the intellectual development by cutting funds (kill Big Bird etc.) and the final stages will be when the citizens become zombies and robots who will support any fascist leader.
Defunding these programs is but a second step in this pathway to zombieland.

newswire.abstract: A celebration for Women’s History Month in an administration where women are rare.

comments.commentBody:
Who knows women better than Donald Trump. He has hosted the beauty pageant for numerous years when he's grabbed the opportunity to sneak into the locker rooms to take a peek. He has toured in a bus and told, on record, about how strongly women are attracted to him and his desire to snag them and their kittens. he even knows how baby girls, including his daughter, grow up to become women who are well endowed. He knows Susan B. Anthony only too well having run his fingers on the coins bearing her visage and wonders if we all have had any acquaintance with her.
Isn't it, therefore, fitting that he speak at such an august event?

newswire.abstract: So far the evidence is conspicuously missing.

comments.commentBody:
Douthat observes that even if Obamacare is not a life saver, it maybe provides a sense of security and peace of mind, which he then dismisses with feint praise and writes that "Security and peace of mind are very good things."
I wonder what he'll say or do if ever he finds out that he has to mortgage his house and savings to take care of himself or his wife/children in case of a catastrophe. These are not just "good things," they are vital for a person's mental peace, especially at a time when other issues will dominate and cause enough stress. I do not wish that situation on Douthat or his family, or for that matter anyone else, but his dismissive stance clearly shows lack of empathy.

newswire.abstract: If Trump explodes private markets, socialized medicine will ultimately grow.

comments.commentBody:
"Passing major social legislation is fantastically difficult. It tends to involve taking something from influential interest groups — taxing the rich, for example (as Obamacare did), or reducing some companies’ profits or hurting professional guilds."
Leonhardt correctly notes that almost all government regulations will involve some redistribution of benefits and welfare. This is the basic social contract which binds citizens and their elected officials. Most folks would like such redistribution to flow from the rich to the poor, from those who are fortunate to have resources to those who are less fortunate and have fewer resources.
However, ever since St. Reagan began his diatribe against government, many but not all Americans have come to view government regulations as a nuisance rather than a welcome intervention. Granted that many government programs are less that efficient but so are many private enterprises.
But in collectively identifying the rich as potential barriers to social reform, Leonhardt does disservice to the many rich and middle-class Americans who believe in a significant role for the government. Just look at some prominent rich folks like Bill Gates and Warren Buffet; they are more than willing to pay additional taxes if it will enhance the welfare of the less fortunate.

newswire.abstract: Truculent Trump has abdicated responsibility. Europe must step into the void.

comments.commentBody:
Cohen accurately says that " at the White House rages a whirlwind of incompetence and ignorance." This was no secret; it was well-known to most Americans but nonetheless Trump managed to inveigle sufficient numbers to sneak his way into the White House. And the "incompetence and ignorance" will continue to blow for the next few years.
Why so, one might ask. The answer is simple. Trump sees everything through one lens and one lens alone. What's the benefit for Trump? And the benefits have to be measured only in monetary units; nothing else makes sense to him.
To put it in even simpler words that even Trump can understand: How much money can I (Trump) make?

newswire.abstract: After the health care debacle, Republicans desperately need a win. Moreover, they are massively underestimating how hard tax reform is going to be.

comments.commentBody:
Brooks starts off on a right note and notes that Trumpcare/Ryancare failed "because it was a bad bill that had almost no authentic public support." He goes on to opine that the planned tax reform - Trumptax/Ryantax - has a better chance of success because "they will start on much stronger ground."

Brooks is a smart pundit except that he suffers from amnesia. The healthcare reform was a subterfuge in that it really gave "tax breaks to the rich few." As for the planned tax reform, there is no need for smoke and mirrors; it will be a direct effort to facilitate a trickle-up flow of money.

Since St. Reagan's days the GOP has been a reverse Robin Hood - tax the poor and help the rich. I don't see how Trumptax/Ryantax will be any different.

comments.commentBody: Paul Ryan was hung out to dry by Trump who is very quick in assigning the blame for any failure on the person sitting next to him at that very moment. But unlike Christie or Giuliani, who were packed off to the farm licking their wounds, Paul Ryan still has the job of Speaker. I doubt if he'll cooperate with Trump in any serious manner as far as tax reform is concerned. Moreover, trump has no clue what such a reform entails. He is not one known to dig into or understand details; he likes to swoop in at the end, stiff a few folks along the way and smile into the cameras pronouncing success. So, I do not expect much more than a lot of hot air from all around. Stay tuned.

newswire.abstract: On politicians who aren’t real leaders, but play leaders on TV.

comments.commentBody:
That Trump is an abomination is not exactly new news. He continues his shenanigans even after winning the White House and has rallies for his reelection in 2020! This much is true and would be horrific, as it is is, except that there are checks-and-balances in the American system of governance. Right? Wrong!
He now has enablers in Congress with Speaker Ryan at its head. He has members in the GOP defending the indefensible. He has subverted the process with his bullying tactics. After all that is the way he has run his family business - bully the workers, stiff the suppliers and creditors. That he is able to continue with the tactics at the highest level of government is a pox on the GOP and our elected representatives.

We, the people, need to get more involved and active in reshaping the Congress in 2018. Are we up to the task?

newswire.abstract: Republicans behind a health care bill found a new way to ignore regular people.

comments.commentBody:
Trump needs a win. He doesn't care how he wins, he needs a win so he can continue feeding his fawning crowd at the rallies. He doesn't care if Trumpcare guts the healthcare for the very people he promised to give a gold-plated, beautiful healthcare. After all he has stiffed many of his workers that stiffing people has become second nature to him. He doesn't care if he has to bully the GOP members in the Congress on his way to a win. After all he bullied his way to the White House. He assigned derogatory names to each of his opponents and whipped up his crowd into a frenzy.

And, if this bill becomes law, he'll continue feeding folks at his rallies the same miasma even as they think it is manna. I am beginning to be less worried about Trump's antics and more worried about the people who continue to see him as their savior. We need a new song "Please cry for me America."

newswire.abstract: As the White House presses for bone-deep spending cuts, some Republican governors have complained about reductions that they see as harmful or arbitrary.

comments.commentBody:
This is what a con artist does. First he sells you a car by hyping its (nonexistent) superb features. This allows him to cash your check as he smiles all the way to the bank. And when you see him the following morning and report that the car wouldn't start, he'll tell you that that was not part of the contract. You now own the car and its problems.

This perfectly describes what is going on except that we - the others that saw through the con man's game - also own the problem. All you Trump voters - THANK YOU!

newswire.abstract: An open letter to the adults in the Trump administration with the most integrity.

comments.commentBody:
Friedman correctly notes that if you let your child get away with the behavior exhibited by Trump, you would "consider yourself a failure as a parent."
But, unlike a child who is likely to change his/her attitudes and behaviors, Trump will only dig in deeper. He has done so time and time again. And for that reason, I do not believe that the five "good men" will have any success even if they had an intervention.

What we need, instead, is for all of them to collectively resign. And, if possible get a few more to join them. This will not change Trump's behavior; he is too enmeshed in seeing himself in the vanity mirror for that. However, it may wake up men and women in Congress who can then grow a spine and start to distance themselves from Trump. They may not be able to impeach him for tweeting, but they certainly can isolate him.

If a tweet falls on no ears or deaf ears, did the tweet occur?

newswire.abstract: The Exodus tale as a national creed.

comments.commentBody:
The common thread in today's narrative is immigration, internal migration, resettlement, and hope. It is a broad brush that applies to some but not many others who have participated in the American drama.

For instance, you note that Frederick Douglas suggested that African-Americans were also part of this hopeful narrative. That almost sounded like what Ben Carson said a few weeks ago when he addresses HUD employees saying that "There were other immigrants who came here in the bottom of slave ships, worked even longer, even harder for less."

Ben Carson's words were cruel, yours not so much, but please do not mix all immigrants and their experiences into one big framework. As you must know a square peg does not fit well in a round hole.

newswire.title: America’s Epidemic of Infallibility

multimedia.caption: President Trump on board Air Force One on Sunday.
President Trump on board Air Force One on Sunday.
President Trump on board Air Force One on Sunday.
President Trump on board Air Force One on Sunday.

newswire.abstract: No apologies, no regrets, no learning from experience.

comments.commentBody:
The Trump anatomy runs on a juice called ego. And he makes sure that the people around him like to run their bodies on the same jet fuel, if not he berates them in public until they succumb. This much was, and is, obvious.

But, as Prof. Krugman speculates, "there’s also something going on in our society: Many Americans no longer seem to understand what a leader is supposed to sound like, mistaking bombast and belligerence for real toughness."

American society was always fueled by machismo all the way from John Wayne to Clint Eastwood. The difference was that they were movie actors portraying tough guys and entertained us. And the real macho leaders, like Teddy Roosevelt, were more than just empty bravado; they also had a brain that functioned. But what has happened today is that the thin line between acting and real life has become blurred. Take the so-called reality shows. Or the WWE run wrestling. Are they real? By now most of us know that the reality portrayed in these shows are actually doctored and faked.

But when the POTUS lets his fingers dance on the keyboard and limits his speech to 140 characters even as he appoints men without character to positions of authority, the entertainment aspect has been drained and the terror of real reality has set in. And that is scary.

newswire.abstract: Stop obsessively checking the latest news on Twitter, CNN and Facebook and you’ll be happier.

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Brooks urges us to "let go of the tree" implying that it is our attachment that makes us unhappy rather than actual circumstances. After all, he goes on to note, it is "maya" or an illusion, we must be confused or hallucinating.
Some of us, and that most certainly includes Mr. Brooks, are fortunate enough to have a normal or above normal life and so can pretend that there are no problems. Those of us who are fortunate to be in this group, and that most certainly includes Mr. Brooks, can then say that all others' troubles are part of "maya" or an illusion. Just don't be confused or hallucinate, and all will be well.
But even after stopping to hallucinate or be confused, some are in a situation, a real one, unlike the world of "maya" conjured by Mr. Brooks, wherein life isn't so kind. I'd urge Mr. Brooks to give up his cushy job and the platinum level healthcare benefits that accompany it for one year and then see how "maya" or Swami Rama help him "let go of the tree."

multimedia.caption: St Benedict
St Benedict
St Benedict
St Benedict

newswire.abstract: One man’s recipe for faith in America.

comments.commentBody:
Christians feeling persecuted in a Christian majority nation is a hoot but for the fact that it is annually propagated by Faux News around Christmas time. It is in the same league as immigrants taking away American jobs, those that no American wants to do like picking vegetables and fruits on a farm.
But such a lie is necessary as a way to organize and mobilize opposition to anything progressive. But in your attempt to agreeably disagree with Rod Dreher, you propose the concept of secular purism in juxtaposition to religious purism. Religion and its messiahs were invariably purists; their only goal was to advance religious orthodoxy. On the other hand, secularists were invariably trying to dismantle such orthodoxy, not create a new one. Thus, the term secular purism is an oxymoron and has no meaning.
Please tell your friend that there are no secular demons living in any closet, maybe only in his mind.

newswire.abstract: It’s not just a bill, it’s the end of an era in American politics.

comments.commentBody:
Prof. Brooks identifies three crises in his lecture. Let me rebut them.
"First, the crisis of opportunity." This is partially because of globalization. It was politically expedient to blame the Chinese and Indians for taking away American jobs. And maliciously exploited by Trump in the recent election. But no one talks about automation. Three robots replace one factory worker. Yes, opportunities were less for those with fewer skills but Obama was pilloried when he suggested expanding access to vocational education.
"Second, the crisis of solidarity." The social fabric disintegrates when one's stresses due to unemployment is compounded by lack of access to healthcare. By now all of us should know who has been crowing from the rooftops about wanting to dismantle Obamacare. Enough said.
"Third, the crisis of authority." When the POTUS lies incessantly and tweets baseless allegations, little wonder trust in institutions is lost. Obama had eight full and scandal free years; Trump has yet to have eight full hours without uttering a lie.
So Prof. Brooks, your analysis is incomplete until you do not identify the culprits who prevented Americans from getting vocational training, denying access to healthcare, and lying to the point where people stop trusting institutions. By not identifying these culprits you seem to suggest an equivalence that is false. Come out and say what you have to say. It is time you called a spade a spade!

newswire.title: Getting Freedom From Health

multimedia.caption: Women protesting Wednesday on Capitol Hill.
Women protesting Wednesday on Capitol Hill.
Women protesting Wednesday on Capitol Hill.
Women protesting Wednesday on Capitol Hill.

newswire.abstract: Janis Joplin had President Trump’s number.

comments.commentBody:
Kevin Brady echoes all of the GOP's sentiment in saying that repealing Obamacare will "begin a new chapter of freedom for the American people." He, and they, don't say freedom from what or to do what. Here is a short list:
1. Freedom to watch a loved one die without access to healthcare.
2. Freedom to go bankrupt while trying to get quality healthcare.
3. Freedom to get back alley and risky abortions.
4. Freedom to die without dignity.
5. Freedom to go to the emergency center at the local hospital.
I think Americans are smart enough to realize that these were the very freedoms they were happy to give up and are being force fed now by the Brady bunch.

newswire.abstract: I credit President Trump — not that he seems any more evolved than the first earthworms now appearing in the cold soil of my garden.

comments.commentBody:
"We have become a lazy, aging, fairly ignorant democracy. Even in the most turbulent election in modern history, about 90 million eligible voters didn’t bother to cast a ballot — the basic task of citizenship."
The world's oldest democracy could take a page or two from the world's largest democracy. In the most recent elections in India, nearly 70% of eligible voters participated. And this included people living in remote and difficult-to-access parts of the country. The entire election was done with electronic voting. These machines were carried on animal back to the remote parts of the country.
Why can't we do that here in today's America?

Make no mistake, behind the softer tome that he struck, he has contempt for everyone and everything that has been carefully constructed over the past centuries. The only person he likes is Donald J. Trump. I am sure he'll throw Ivanka or Jared under the bus if that bus will help him forge ahead. One swallow doth not a summer make, one speech doth not unmake a vicious narcissist.

newswire.title: Democracy, Disrupted
newswire.abstract: “Someone looking at the United States would have to be worried about democratic failure.”

comments.commentBody: The title of this column makes the same mistake that has been made many times over. Technological progress, such as the capacity to design and manufacture a horseless carriage, or crack the atom to make a terrifying explosion, or the internet that allows unfiltered and unfettered communication, are all just that - technological progress. They are used by people to either benefit or harm society. Whether they are used to benefit or harm depends on two elements: prevailing laws and institutions as also on the capacity for critical thinking among people. Currently we have failure in at least one of these two elements. Our citizens capacity to critically think and screen information is woefully absent. People are wont to pass along anything that comes into their inbox. The internet merely amplifies our collective inability to think critically.

comments.commentBody:
Another brilliant column by Ms. Collins which she concludes with "Take your pick. They’ll all be around for the next four years."
That is a tad generous on her part to give him four more years. Listen closely to the chatter about Trump campaigners contacting Russian officials prior to the election. Follow that lead. What were they discussion? I am sure it wasn't recipes to bake a cake. More likely it was a recipe to cook the election.
Also follow the money. Why hasn't Trump released his tax returns? No banks in America would lend him money. He was not a good credit risk. Remember how he got others to bail him out 20 years ago and stuck them with the debt while he took the tax write off? Overseas banks with Russian connections must have lent him the money. As Deep Throat said, "Follow the money."

newswire.abstract: The parallels between Brexit and Trumpism are profound.

comments.commentBody:
Friedman notes that "the Brexiters and Trumpsters want to return us to a globe of everyone-for-themselves nationalisms that helped to foster two world wars."
At least the Brexiter and Trumpsters want to return to nationalism but Trump is worse than even Trumpsters because he wants a return on only Trump investments. Every action of his has been calculated to improve his and his family business' standing.

In promoting this narrow idea of nationalism, Trump has exploited the free movement of people and the resultant relocation across the globe. Just like in the UK, immigrants to the USA have added net value. They do jobs for which there are not enough qualified Americans such as software and engineering or jobs that Americans are loathe to doing such as hard labor on a farm. And yet they are used as punching bags by Trump and his minions.

This also conveniently overlooks the real force at work, i.e., technological revolution that has made possible for robots to replace workers at the rate of 3-to-1. The real solution is for more Americans to get better educated and become a part of the new technological world that is only going to get more technology driven.

Brexiters and Trumpsters have let their anger morph into a short sighted movement that may temporarily salve their angst but will hurt the country and the world in the long run.

newswire.abstract: Republicans are running up against a surge of activism as well as the impossibility of achieving a better and cheaper plan that covers everyone.

comments.commentBody:
"There is no free lunch on health care. Your health "costs" pay for my health "benefits," and vice versa."

This fundamental economic principle is true in case of not just healthcare but all other facets of public expenditures. And that is why exclusively cutting taxes that is promised to pay for all public expenditures is a hoax. It was a lie when St. Reagan promised it, and continues to be a lie today. And yet the Republicans offer that solution. That is sad, so sad.

But what is sadder is that a segment of Americans believe and buy into that. Somehow they seem to believe in magic or fairy dust. It was a lie when Trump, while campaigning, promised a better and cheaper healthcare for everyone. And the crowds roared.

Maybe I should have attended those rallies and sold them Brooklyn bridge!

newswire.abstract: Why should people not conclude there’s no moral code any more and what’s needed is a guy to blow up the system?

comments.commentBody:
Cohen asks an important question: Why do people vote against their self-interest and elect hucksters? In answering this question he misses an important point - education, or to be more precise, the lack of it.
By education I do not mean a high school or college degree, although those are helpful. By education I mean awareness and knowledge of one's location in the universe and our impact on the surrounding micro and macro ecosystems. If only people paused to think about these matters, we'd be more thoughtful in our actions and elect sensible folks to be our leaders. Unfortunately pettiness rules and is being peddled and provoked. Evreryone is asked to think of none other than oneself. We believe we are an island.
Sadly and scarily this leads to all the outcomes Cohen talks about.

Abraham Lincoln was a classic Enlightenment man. President Trump is an anti-Enlightenment man.

newswire.abstract: When anti-Enlightenment movements arose in the past, Enlightenment heroes rose to combat them.

comments.commentBody:
"Enlightenment thinkers turned their skeptical ideas into skeptical institutions, notably the U.S. Constitution. America’s founders didn’t trust the people or themselves, so they built a system of rules, providing checks and balances to pit interest against interest."

Granted that these thinkers crafted rules and checks and balances so that individuals cannot usurp power and destroy the nation. But, in the process, you underestimate the role and importance of enlightened people. Those who crafted these rules were not perfect but were enlightened (mostly) men. All the figures you reference including Lincoln were enlightened folks. I'd add Obama to that list, although you demur and don't reference him.
My point is that merely having enlightened rules is not sufficient. It is a necessary condition but required enlightened men to make it function effectively. And right now we have a carnival barker, which in my book is the opposite of an enlightened person, at the helm of affairs. The result is the chaos we find ourselves in.
Enlightened rules + enlightened people = Rule of Law.

newswire.abstract: Civil society needs to take a stand.

comments.commentBody:
"Mr. Trump is clearly a would-be autocrat, and other Republicans are his willing enablers."
Absolutely correct. And before the Republicans we had a large swath of Americans enabling Trump and his autocracy, better known as autoCRAZY. Many are calling for understanding the pain and anguish of this segment. But I look at them as enablers. They deserve our sympathy only in modest doses. They deserve our sympathy no more than a person who watches a store getting vandalized but does not call the police or do anything else to stop the vandal. Are we supposed to have sympathy for that person? Or do we label him/her an enabler?

An outraged citizenry "may be our last defense" as Krugman suggests. But I still have faith in the judiciary. So far they have been doing the right thing. Let us hope they continue to be at the vanguard of this resistance.

newswire.abstract: The press is the light that makes the roaches scatter.

comments.commentBody:
What is the most common pronoun used by Priebus, Bannon, Conway, Trump and many others in this administration when speaking of the ills facing this country? THEY! It is never a named source; it is always THEY.

By not clarifying who is the real target of the charges being leveled, it is easy to slip and slither within a loosely formed accusation. In the process it is also easy to "otherize" meaning that one does not have to look at oneself for answers. There is always the "other" who is responsible.

This administration does not want light shined on it for, after all, as Blow notes, "The press is the light that makes the roaches scatter." Will it make the head roach scatter and run away or be pushed out? That remains to be seen.

newswire.abstract: Starting with a way to fight the social crisis.

comments.commentBody:
Douthat notes that "an emergency response would set a more ambitious goal: a swift boost in work force participation and family formation."

I prefer to stay out of people's pants and let families form the way they form. But, as far as workforce participation, I have a simple idea. Why not go to a 36 or even a 32 hour week? What is so sacred about 40-hour week? Automation is here to stay and is already having its impact in various manufacturing sectors. In the automotive sector it is estimated that one robot will replace three workers.

So, why not modify our work week? A 32-hour week will not only expand participation in the workforce but also open up time that could be used for creative pursuits. Who has not heard someone, maybe oneself, say, "If only I had some free time I'd take up painting or dancing."

You wanted radical proposals. Make the work week 32 hours. How is that for a radical proposal?

newswire.abstract: What Republicans mean when they talk about freedom.

comments.commentBody:
Talk of freedom is the real refuge of scoundrels. Bravo for pointing that out.

In this logic you are free to fall sick and what can be better than freely choosing a doctor. Of course such freedom is not open to a woman who wishes to use contraception or terminate her pregnancy. In that case, you are free to die.

Talk of freedom is nothing more than a sleight of hand that switches the focus from access to choice. When there is no access, what does choice mean?

comments.commentBody:
"You throw around terms like "atmospheric river," "climate change," and others like those. But wait, look outside the window. The sky is there, it is blue, and the sun did rise in the east this morning. You must belong to the cadre of fake meteorologists joining the team of fake news media persons. You rabble-rousers have nothing else to do other than to scare poor Americans into believing that the sky is falling. Sad, very sad.
And now let me sign my executive order banning any further issuance of weather reports. This executive order is intended to protect Americans from the fake weathermen who have traumatized them with fake information thus far.
Moreover, that is what Steve asked me to tell you."

signed -- DJT

Senators Tom Cotton, left, and David Perdue unveiled legislation this month to cut immigration in half.

newswire.abstract: Two senators with a recipe for American stagnation.

comments.commentBody:
"Cotton and Perdue’s position, which is now the mainstream Republican position, is based on the unconscious supposition that American society is like a lake, with a relatively fixed boundary. If you cut the supply of fish coming from outside, there will be more food for the ones born here."

This metaphor describing the Republican position has to be interpreted differently. American society is like a lake. I am a fish that was lucky to get in, either because my parents migrated here or because I just seeped through the border. Now I want to make sure that other fish do not come into my lake. It is now MY lake.

comments.commentBody:
"If Democrats want to battle voter suppression, it’s crucial to win local races — including in white working-class districts in Ohio, Wisconsin and elsewhere."

I have one word why Dems are losing the local elections. GERRYMANDERING. Districts have been carved out in a manner that protects the incumbent against anyone. BTW, the Dems are also at fault in this regard. It is simply that their districts are more dense and closely packed thereby negating its effectiveness.

As for not demonizing Trump voters and supporters, I have to ask this question: Does a bystander who actively eggs on a racist and homophobic person get a pass because s/he is actually not racist or homophobic? Is it OK to watch a guy vandalize and note that you personally do not support vandalism or vandalize yourself? At the very least Trump supporters are enabling intolerable actions and behaviors. And for that there is no excuse.

Oil - it will be gushing in every backyard.

Guns - oh yes, small sizes are available for kids in kindergarten.

Water - there's plenty of bottled water available in stores, the clean ones cost a bit more, but isn't your life worth it, so pay a bit more won't you.

newswire.abstract: Add them up and see if they work together.

comments.commentBody:
Four of the characterizations - Entertainment, Cleanup, Crazy, and GOP - are all enablers of the Essential Trump. Each enabler has his/her/its own agenda. Americans who watch and support him do so for entertainment value. Pence, the cleanup guy, does it in the hope that he'll get to be POTUS when his boss gets impeached. Crazy Bannon is in it because he's crazy and interested in molding America in Breitbart's image. Priebus, the GOP guy, is interessted in advancing the GOP agenda - tax cuts, kill Obamacare, rape the environment, etc.
In the meantime Essential Trump is doing what he loves to do - speak to adoring crowds and advance his personal business interests in America and the world over. In the not too distant future even his adoring crowds will get bored by his nonstop antics and begin to dwindle. In the meantime Essential Trump will have 'Madoff' with sweet deals and America would have been the loser.
Welcome to Essential Trump's La-La land!

newswire.abstract: He has business ties, political ties and ideological ties to Putin’s Russia, and it’s up to the Senate and the F.B.I. to clarify them.

comments.commentBody:
45 deserves no benefit of the doubt as far as his business interests in Russia are concerned. He has not released his tax returns. We are entitled to believe that he is deeply invested in Russia and with Russian money.
Take the deeply flawed two-week old and now defunct ban on immigrants. It was directed at seven countries that had little to do with terrorism but also places where 45 had no business interests. OTOH Saudi Arabia and Egypt were excluded from that list. Not only did they have a deeper connection with terrorism but those are two places where 45 has business interests.
We always knew that 45 cared about one thing only - him and his business interests. He tweeted about Nordstrom dropping his daughter's line of clothing. Who does that? A delusional narcissist who does anything and everything to benefit himself.
Case closed.

As for Russia annexing Crimea. 45 will take Vlad, his BFF, out to dinner and tell him that that is a no-no. Russian troops will be pulled out even before 45 has settled the dinner tab.

This is one of the most ignorant person. It is the unwillingness to learn that is.

newswire.abstract: The decline of economic growth is at the bottom of ethnic nationalism’s rise, faith in democracy’s fall and world order’s dissipation.

comments.commentBody:
The title of this column is strange for two reasons.
First, it is only 17 years old, and that too not fully. And it has been written off? It is like telling a high-school kid who's been getting mediocre grades that his life is over. Granted that things may be a bit less than desirable but to dismiss the entire century based on a short period is dispirited and defeatist.
Second, it shows a very American point of view. The "us" and the "we" are all about America and Americans, ONLY. It is as though the rest of the world doesn't matter. Even if you grant that America casts a large shadow on the world, it is extremely insular and parochial to view the century through nothing but an American lens.
I can see technology replacing human labor which can then be focused on more creative pursuits. But that will only happen if we can see the world through a humanist lens, not just as an input into the productivity hopper. Each one of us is much more than just a component in the assembly line as depicted in Chaplin's "Modern Times." Sadly, out political leaders and captains of industry have yet to evolve to this higher plane of thinking. Until then, it is not the century, but the world and human spirit that are broken.

comments.commentBody:
Prof. Krugman notes that a budget based on a robust 3.0% - 3.5% growth is unlikely because currently unemployment is below 5%. But he does not realize that that is an alternate fact. Only 45 knows the real unemployment rate which is "probably 20 percent, but I will tell you, you have some great economists that will tell you it's a 30, 32. And the highest I've heard so far is 42 percent."

So, there you are Prof. Krugman, budget assumption explained!

comments.commentBody:
"Like all narcissists, he doesn’t like to be told if he’s screwing up, so he surrounds himself with people who don’t tell him."
This is the perfect precursor for a dictatorial leader to emerge from under the veneer of a democratic one. Does anyone remember that Chairman Mao was often told that e was the best musician and ping-pong player in China? If you don;t recall those days, think of King Jon Un. You think anybody wants to tell him that he's a bit chubby?
Watch out America. 45 is on his way to centralize power and trust no one else. It is not hyperbolic to envision and believe that the constitution will protect and save us from that fate. We require people to interpret and use the force of our constitution to avoid that fate. And I do not see anyone in the Congress ready to stand up to 45.

newswire.abstract: There’s a simple (legal) way to replace a president. But it has never been attempted.

comments.commentBody:
The root cause of why we are where we are is the gerrymandering of congressional districts. It defies logic to give the power of redistricting to those who have a vested interest. It is akin to having the proverbial fox guarding the chicken coop. How can we ever get a congressman to understand that gerrymandering is not good for the country's governance. As Upton Sinclair said, ""It is difficult to get a man to understand something, when his salary depends upon his not understanding it!"
So, we are stuck with this system until there is enough of a mess - BTW, the current election of 45 hardly counts as a major mess in this regard - to make an amendment that takes away the responsibility of redistricting from the local state representatives and places it with an independent election commission. In this regard India and a few other countries are way ahead of the USA.

On top of that he still has no strong opposition in the Congress which makes it much more scary.
My faith is in the judiciary. And so far that branch is the only one to show some spine.

comments.commentBody:
If in less than one month we can talk about 45 being at the bottom of the Presidential list,
If in less than one month we can talk about possible impeachment hearings,
If in less than one month we have had the Veep to break a tie in confirming a cabinet member,
If in less than one month we have the first member resign under a dark cloud of suspicion,
If in less than one month we've had a series of judicial decisions rescinding an executive order,
If in less than one month we have had more protest marches across the country and the world than in the entire tenure of another president,

We have truly entered a space and time unlike any before. And so, 45 did not inherit a mess, as he claimed recently, but it is we who have elected a mess.

comments.commentBody:
"Even after these horrible four weeks, Republicans on Capitol Hill are not close to abandoning their man."
As your hero St. Reagan would have said, "There you go again."
Yes, you are absolutely right that the spineless Repugnants are not close to doing anything that will adversely affect their own and their party's agenda of tax cutting. They stand for one thin and one thing alone - cut taxes; cut taxes to the bode so that the average American can be bone dry trying to make a living while the rich reap all the benefits.
Yes, you are also right 45 will ride on the 35% that blindly and foolishly support, nay, adore him. Little do they realize that they are nothing more than pawns in 45's delusions. He will be going down to Florida and holding a rally! Did somebody not tell him that the election is over and he is currently the sole occupant of the White House?
But there is much more to this stench than that. You fail to mention the right wing pundits who've been egging on the crazy right wing nuts. This group deserves just as much blame for the current mess. Please make sure you mention that in your next column.

comments.commentBody: I was intrigued by ICE union endorsing 45, but did not make much of it. Now when I read that the union president filed suit against the US government and, more importantly, that they were represented by Kris Kobach, he of the millions-of-illegals-voted-for-Hillary-Clinton fame, I am convinced that ICE is waiting to enforce the law, not as humanely as possible, but as inhumanely as possible. While I understand that ICE officers are the front line in a difficult and contentious context, there is no need to be uncivil and inhumane. That is not just un-American, it is un-human.

comments.commentBody:
"From the start, the Trump administration was a dark combination of mean and inept." Collins hits the nail on the head with this description of our now government. It is dark - listen to all the bad news in the world, look at how the media is always faking news, etc. It is inept - even Hollywood would shy away from a story in which the American President discusses a missile launch in a public place with flashlights from a cell phone.
Truth, as they say, is often stranger than fiction. And nothing can be stranger than how or why 45 got elected. When do you think the Republican party will turn on the president? Many have started to flee this sinking ship, and 45 has not even had one entire month on the job.
Once the Republicans have decided not to attach themselves to this man-baby and open up an investigation into Russiagate, people will begin to talk, just to save their own skin, and things around 45 will begin to fall like dominoes.
Do you think the college-senior-who-never-got-out-of-college Miller or the I-am-in-the-loop-or-oops-am-I-out-of-the-loop Conway will save themselves or protect 45? Forget defending the illegals who streamed into New Hampshire from Massachusetts. Forget putting in a plug for the Ivanka line of clothing. When do you think they'll start singing?
I hope enough Americans, especially those who voted for 45, see that running a private family business does not automatically give one the ability to run the country.

comments.commentBody:
Since he rarely reads or has any interest or knowledge in history, 45 may not know what Harry Truman had on his desk. Readers of this column and the rest of us know that President Truman had a sign "The buck stops here" on his desk meaning that he bore ultimate responsibility for all decisions.
45 may have been able to bypass his conversation with Billy Bush as "locker room talk" and no more. He may have been able to duck under the media gaze and never release his tax returns. We know he is prone to taking no responsibility and is always pointing his finger at someone else.
This may, however, prove to be a more difficult one to duck. He may rue the day he chose to get Flynn on board his team. And, if it isn't Flynn, someone else on that team - Bannon, Miller, Conway - will bite back when 45 throws them under the bus.
Bottom line: You live in a swamp and keep company with vile critters, you'll be dragged down the swamp or be badly bitten by one of them.

Welcome to today's world where up is down and wrong is right.

comments.commentBody:
Friedman is merely echoing what President Carter noted in his book more than a decade ago.
While on a book tour, Carter said, ""When Israel does occupy this territory deep within the West Bank, and connects the 200-or-so settlements with each other, with a road, and then prohibits the Palestinians from using that road, or in many cases even crossing the road, this perpetrates even worse instances of apartness, or apartheid, than we witnessed even in South Africa."
It has been going on for a long time, a very long time. The inevitable end will be sad - Israel will be swallowed by the demographic deluge.

newswire.abstract: American scientists should learn from their northern neighbors. Reject interference. Stay vigilant. Stay scientists.

comments.commentBody:
Martin Niemoller's poem is well-known to many. In it he refers to the different segments of the population that come under attack, but he never singled out scientists. When they come for scientists, it means they are trying to muzzle the little thread of reality that may exist. And once that is also excised, their taking over is complete.
But let us not leave it to the scientists alone to fight this fight; let us all back them and support them in this fight. We need scientists more than they need us. No science, no knowledge.

comments.commentBody:
"The baby boomer establishment polarized politics, lost touch with the voters and paved the way for Trump. We need a new establishment, one that works again."

You lie. Yes, and I mean it. The boomers are responsible for many ills, but please do not lump Trump on them. Why not blame the 53% white women who voted for him in spite of his well known misogyny? Why not blame the Hispanics who voted for him in spite of his racist ethnocentric views? And, lastly, why not blame the punditry that kept egging on the Republican party for eight long years when sanity prevailed?

There is a lot of blame to go around, but lumping it all on the boomers is yet another lie.

newswire.byline: By GAIL COLLINS and BENJAMIN DOMENECH
newswire.title: No More Rules of the Game
newswire.abstract: In the Trump administration, even the disruptions are being disrupted.

comments.commentBody:
Where do we begin?
Collins: "His counselor violates the ethics rules by telling TV viewers to buy Ivanka Trump’s clothing line." And the Republicans let out a big yawn. It is business as usual, as long as she did not use her private server to send out that message. After all she only said it with words on national TV. DOn't we all know that words have no meaning?

Domenech: "And how quickly they went from not having an Obamacare replacement to having too many!" Is this guy for real? Is he serious? Anyone can come up with a hundred zillion alternate plans. After all they are the masters of the alternate fact. In fact they invented it. So, is having "too many" alternate plans good? The more serious question he should've asked is whether there is even one reasonable plan.

Collins: "Calvinball is a great game — different every time, as the only rule is that you can’t use the same rules twice."

Domenech: "Personally, I still think the idea of replacing Medicaid with $100 in cash and a kitten for everyone has merit."

On substance and in quality of humor, Ms. Collins wins. But Mr. Domenech wins the electoral college. I am sorry, but that is the system.

newswire.abstract: Trump’s focus on refugees diverts from real dangers.

comments.commentBody:
Kristof presents strong and convincing arguments in this column. There are far more dangerous things in life than the refugees allowed to enter the USA. And guns would be in that list.
However, the logic presented will fall on deaf ears. Many will cite the second amendment and parrot the phrase "the right to bear arms" without quoting the entire amendment. It was written at a time when the country was newly minted and faith in the ability to govern themselves in a democratic system was uncertain. There was the fear tat the government might overrun its own citizens and hence the ability to organize a citizen army (or militia) was formulated as an antidote.
This right to bear arms, in today's context, as far as opposing the government is laughable, at best. A people's militia with the best guns available in the marketplace is no match to the US army's arsenal.
Sadly, this logic will fall on deaf ears. But I thank Kristof for continuing to raise this issue, because that is the only way we are likely to enforce sensible gun regulation.

This helped them stall some bills but they also hurt their standing and brand name. The same may happen to the Democrats if they use these parliamentary tactics. To offset the damages to their standing and brand name, the Democrats must also keep up the pressure in the court of public opinion. And in that court, Trump is at a serious disadvantage. The Democrats must continue driving his ratings further down.

newswire.abstract: Yes, giddy times for the opposition. But they are more removed from power than at almost any point in history.

comments.commentBody:
We focus on Trump and his shenanigans, as serious as they may be, but we really ought to focus on two other things.
First, we ought to focus on the American people's education and ability to sift fact from fiction. It is their lack of this ability that provides the oxygen for Trump's haphazard, chaotic, and ultimately dangerous actions.
Second, we ought to focus on the local elections. We have legislators who are supine and fully neutered by Trump. Paul Ryan, the so-called intelligent one leading the GOP, reverses himself so fast and so frequently that his head must be spinning. Let us all resolve to elect sane, rational people to the Congress.
In these dark times, we do have a silver lining - the judiciary. So far they have been the only line of resistance to a madman. I hope they will continue to be the bulwark against this administration.
Finally, as Egan suggests, the Dems must "engage in hand-to-hand combat in the capital" but we can help them by electing sensible people at the local and state levels.

newswire.abstract: The truth under siege: 2+2 does not equal 5.

comments.commentBody:
"Fact-based journalism is a ridiculous, tautological phrase. It’s like talking about oxygen-based human life. There is no other kind.
Yes, there is another kind - it is called FOX NEWS. This channel has been spewing untruths and half-truths for as long as I can remember. So much so that a large number of Americans depend on that source for their information.
And that brings me to the sad reality, a reality that is not politically correct to utter, and yet Horner had the courage to utter. He noted, “Honestly people are definitely dumber. They just keep passing stuff around. Nobody fact-checks anything anymore — I mean, that’s how Trump got elected."
This is a sad commentary on the state of our citizenry. Ant-intellectualism has become the norm. Anyone who has a college education must be an elite. Anyone who knows that the earth revolves around the sun rather than the other way is an elite.
Since readers of this column must be elites, I am sure they recall the punishment meted out people like Galileo for speaking the truth. Those were the dark days from which we emerged. But lately it seems that we've reentered the dark ages once again.

newswire.abstract: Trump made a series of reckless, unconnected promises to get elected, and now he’s just checking off each one.

comments.commentBody:
Trump's actions thus far have been chaotic and reckless. Fundamental logic, such as is evident in your arguments, are not the way he thinks or operates; he acts from his gut, as he has himself noted from time to time. That approach helped him get elected, and he assumes it will also help him govern. He does not seem to recognize the big difference between campaigning and governing. And that is the scary part.
The scarier part of this unfolding drama is that many Americans are on board his crazy train. They voted him into office, if not via a majority of votes by number count, but by handing him the electoral college. And now, close to one-half support his thinly veiled Muslim ban. In other words, his supporters are hanging on his coattails even now; they are all in. And that has to be the scarier part.
Members of the GOP are silently following his lead. Very few speak up against his crazy policies. And those who do, do so in muted voices. And only infrequently. They have been neutered.
So, bottom line, Trump is behaving in an irresponsible manner. And many Americans are still in the "America First" stupor. The GOP is impotent, often by its own choice. The only hope I have is for the judiciary to rise up, check this megalomaniac, and save us from catastrophe.

"Today, I’d say the most pivotal spot on earth is Washington, D.C. The crucial questions will be settled there: Can Donald Trump be induced to govern in some rational manner or will he blow up the world?"

The most important place is not Washington, D.C. but the brain of the denizen of the White House. There are far too many cobwebs in them to call it functional, even at a basic level. And, in that sense the most important places might be the neuroscience labs that may find a cure for extreme narcissism. We need that cure faster than we think we need it. For otherwise, as you note, he will blow up the world.

Take for instance the leaked policy to revive black sites overseas. When there was a push back, some from his own cabinet, he said that Mattis “will override because I’m giving him that power.” In Trump's world anyone with a counter view is allowed to have that counter view by Trump because they cannot have a view of their own.
This is the ultimate evidence of extreme narcissism. This man is unfit for any office, leave alone that of the POTUS.

newswire.abstract: This isn’t a strategy; it’s a syndrome.

comments.commentBody:
Krugman notes that Trump's foreign policy "is looking less and less like a political strategy and more and more like a psychological syndrome."
YES, YES, and YES! We have elected a man who is an egotist and narcissist. History buffs will remember monarchs from centuries ago who waged war for personal vendetta. Why, as recently as 2003, George W. Bush invaded Iraq because Saddam Hussein had threatened to assassination his father a few years back. And he was no monarch from the past.
If that was possible as recently as 2003, with Trump at the helm, anything is possible. Be worried, deeply worried.

newswire.abstract: The true American myth is dynamic and universal, yet the countermyth of Trump and Bannon is winning.

comments.commentBody:
"The odd thing is that the Trump-Bannon myth is winning."
And do you know why this myth is winning? It is the result of relentless, non-stop barrage of anti-science, anti-intellectualism, anti-immigrants, anti-common sense that has been spewing from Fox News for the past two decades. It is the result of pundits like you who have been pushing the GOP agenda over the same period. It is the result of the GOP which has been unwilling to challenge this downward trend. Where were you when Obama was delegitimized from day one by Mitch McConnell and his pals? No wonder the Trump-Bannon myth is winning.
Unfortunately, even though you helped make it, we all own it now. Why, for that matter, even in this column you write, "That American myth was embraced and lived out by everybody from Washington to Lincoln to Roosevelt to Reagan." Why do you stop at Reagan? You are still unwilling to include Obama as part of that rich American tradition. Why? Obama saved the American economy that was ravaged and savaged by his predecessor. He saved the auto industry. Don't you remember?
If you as a scholar and a pundit do not see the need to include Obama in that list, why do you expect the average American will? Little wonder the Trump-Bannon myth is winning.

comments.commentBody:
Douthat notes that a country-by-country restriction is on "more solid populist ground." Maybe. But it is inarguable that the seven countries identified are not the primary exporters of radical jihadists. How soon we forget that the bulk of the 9/11 hijackers came from Egypt. How soon we forget that it was in the Khobar Tower bombing in Saudi Arabia that many Americas died. Both these countries are notably absent from this list.
Is it because Trump has properties in these countries? One has to wonder about the selective nature in which these seven countries were cherry picked. This may be populist, although one could argue that as well, but definitely not sensible. It also has a whiff of malfeasance.

newswire.abstract: Democrats need to take the long view.

comments.commentBody:
In an accompanying column Cohen calls Trump's behavior "banal belligerence." He will fight anything and everything and there is nothing small enough that he'll let go. Take for instance his beef with CNN reporter Jim Acosta. Trump refused to take his question and pointedly called him and his employer "fake news organization." It would an insult to children to call this childish behavior.
But, I have a suggestion for reporters and those in the media. When Trump refuses to take a question from a reporter, any reporter from any news organization, the very next reporter MUST ask the very same question. And, if Trump refuses to answer that reporter, the very next reporter MUST ask the very same question. If Trump continues to refuse answering that question and walks away, which I fully expect him to do, the American public can see his churlish behavior on full display. Let us see how long he can avoid questions, change the topic, or hurl insults at journalists.
C'mon media folks, you can do this, can't you?

newswire.title: Repeal and Compete

Susan Collins and Bill Cassidy at a news conference introducing their plan for health care reform.

newswire.abstract: A possible health care compromise would put conservative ideas to a test.

comments.commentBody:
The Cassidy-Collins compromise proposal would allow states to decide the fate of Obamacare. It "would remain intact in most blue states for the time being, while redder states would have the opportunity to turn roughly the same amount of money (95 percent) to a different end."
I do not like this compromise, but given our current state of affairs and the Republican majority, this may be a good and viable option. And let us suppose it plays out and becomes the law of the land. We'll see how the blue states thrive on healthcare indices indices whereas the red states will have far more deleterious conditions.
We've seen how this plays out already in case of state taxes. Governor Brownback cut taxes in Kansas with the stated intention of spurring economic growth; we all saw the state spiral downwards rather than upwards. Expect the same in case of the differential healthcare systems if left to the states.
